newsitem.title: KENYA: IMF decision on aid shakes Kenya, shilling slumps.
newsitem.headline: IMF decision on aid shakes Kenya, shilling slumps.

text.p: An IMF decision to halt a key aid package because of corruption and a lack of reform shook Kenya on Friday, sending the Kenyan shilling into a slump and scaring foreign investors.
In the first official reaction, Central Bank Governor Micah Cheserem called for urgent damage limitation and said the IMF had dealt a serious blow to Kenya's international credibility.
"This is an unfortunate development but we must face it. We must not condemn (the IMF). What is important is damage limitation that will ensure the economy is not severely hurt," he told Reuters.

The IMF said on Thursday a $205 million three-year loan, offered under its Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF), was allowed to lapse because the response of President Daniel arap Moi's government to a July 24 deadline for change had been inadequate.

The Kenyan shilling opened at 59/59.50 to the dollar but weakened to 60/62.50 in 20 minutes. By noon (0900 GMT), the shilling was trading at an average of 62 to the dollar and 100 to sterling from 58.92 and 96.6 respectively on Thursday.
Cheserem said the central bank was weighing intervening to back the shilling but it was not prudent to attempt to stop a stampede because it might only add to the shilling's weakness.
He said he was concerned at the domino effect of the IMF decision with worries over reaction from the World Bank, foreign bilateral donors, inflation and possible tax increases.
Analysts estimated the IMF move would cost Kenya hundreds of millions of dollars in lost investment and foreign bilateral donors would also have a reason to cut aid to the country.
The IMF turned down a request from Moi's government for more time to try to take measures to meet IMF concerns about corruption and its demands for reform of the energy sector.
At the Nairobi Stock Exchange, brokers watched an empty board for deals by foreigners. "Foreign investors don't want to put their money into a sea of uncertainty," said one broker.
"Clearly the pressure was on from the IMF. If the government had called their bluff, no one in Kenya would believe the IMF had teeth," said a top market analyst who declined to be named.

"Short term foreign investors will leave mainly because they are people who do not necessary know the country too well and are coming in on the basis of an IMF programme," he added. "The lack of an IMF programme in Kenya is fundamental for them."

"We had made strong gains in the field of economic reform in the last few years and that IMF decision will take us back two to three steps," said John Munge, managing director at leading brokerage house Shah, Munge & Partners.
Kenya's opposition hailed the IMF decision, saying it would hit projects and foreign investment but damage was necessary to pressure the government into reforms before a general election this year.

"I'm very pleased the IMF has finally recognised the enormous problem of governance in this country," said Richard Leakey, secretary-general of the unregistered Safina party which campaigned for political reforms and against corruption.
"We have been asking the IMF for a very long time to take this measure and obviously it will hit a lot of projects," he told Reuters. "Corruption was absolutely central to the IMF decision."
An opposition-backed alliance campaigning for political reforms has called for a nationwide general strike on August 8 to put more pressure on Moi, 73 and in power for 19 years.
In an editorial written before news of the IMF decision, the independent Daily Nation newspaper said on Friday the IMF clearly believed the government was loathe to punish corruption.

"The perception in the donor community is that the government has played hide and seek with the IMF over the Goldenberg scam," said the Nation, referring to a multi-million dollar financial scandal involving Goldenberg International.

"We think the reason why there is reluctance to punish corruption in government is that it is highly placed people who are involved...Such highly placed people are involved in corruption because they know they will go scott-free," it said.
The IMF has focused on the Goldenberg scandal to illustrate how authorities were wary about cracking down on corruption.
Goldenberg International was paid about $100 million by the government in 1992 under a compensation scheme for gold and diamond exports. Kenya produces little gold and no diamonds.
The opposition had cited alleged links to powerful Kenyan politicians as the main reason why the case dragged on.
